awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Modulating Local Tumor Hypoxia using Cryogel Scaffolds to Regulate Dendritic Cell Function and Activity
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Abstract
Hypoxia is an abnormal decrease of oxygen levels in tissues.  Although different tissues and cells have distinct thresholds and susceptibility to hypoxia, at a cellular level, hypoxia and hypoxic responses generally occur at approximately 1-3 % oxygen.  Compelling evidence has shown that reduced tissue oxygenation is present in various diseases, and more particularly cancer.  A large number of human solid tumors profoundly lack oxygen, exhibiting hypoxic tumor areas; this condition is mainly due to an imbalance between delivery of oxygen via the blood circulation and consumption by cancer cells.  Hypoxia can arise via a number of mechanisms.  For instance, fast growing hypoxic tumors typically have poor vessel bio-distribution, increased vascular defects, and low vessel number.  Furthermore, highly proliferating cancer cells that outgrow the neovascularization also participate in tumor hypoxia.  An increasing list of cancers with hypoxic regions has been reported over the last decade and include endometrial carcinoma, ovarian, melanoma, lymphoma, breast, bladder, brain, head and neck, renal, colon, gastric, pancreatic, prostate, and non-small cell lung cancers.  The research objective of this proposal is to apply standard methods of biomaterials science and engineering to emulate a hypoxic tumor microenvironment and better understand the interplay between tumor and dendritic cells, the major directors of immune responses.  The proposed studies are likely to offer new modalities in cancer immunotherapy and are expected to justify the use of hypoxia-suppressive biomaterials, reinforce tumoricidal functions of immune cells, and ultimately increase tumor rejections.  The educational goal of this proposal is to introduce biomaterials science and engineering to high school students (develop hands-on science curriculum, promote practical research experience, and foster STEM field trips to the campus), enhance undergraduate research exposure and experience to underrepresented students (Hispanic, African-American, and female), and expand the Northeastern University co-op model to include graduate and academic lab experiences.  

Technical Abstract
Hypoxic cancers are usually aggressive, resistant to standard therapies, and thus very difficult to eradicate. A better understanding of how these hypoxic cancer cells interact with the immune system would allow tailoring of efficient therapies and better outcomes. Hypoxia can inhibit differentiation, antigen capture, maturation, lymph node homing of dendritic cells (DCs), the main regulators of immune responses, which can impair downstream T cell development, differentiation and cytotoxic activity.  Immunosuppression represents one of the fundamental tumor immune evasion mechanisms.  Therefore, it is important to expand our understanding on how hypoxia affects DCs and find ways to circumvent hypoxia-driven immunosuppression locally and restore immune cell function and activity.  To address this need, the primary research objective of this proposal is to engineer biomaterials to modulate the local hypoxic environment to understand immune cell function and activity.  To achieve this goal, this proposal has three aims: 1) Design injectable oxygen-generating cryogel scaffolds to controllably deliver oxygen, 2) Engineer a B16-F10 melanoma tumor microenvironment in three-dimension and deliver oxygen locally to modulate inherent and tumor-induced hypoxia, and 3) Disrupt hypoxia and modulate oxygen tension to understand how local oxygenation can regulate dendritic cell survival and function and impact their activity in an in-vitro ovalbumin (B16-F10/OVA) melanoma model.  The long-term educational goal of the proposal is to promote and train the next generation of scientists to work in academia, industry and clinical settings developing innovative biomaterials to improve human quality of life. The major aims of this program are: 1) Introduce K-12 students to Biomaterials Science (develop a hands-on science curriculum, implement practical research experience, and foster STEM field trips to campus), 2) Enhance undergraduate research exposure and experience to underrepresented students (Hispanic, African-American, and female), and 3) Expand the Northeastern University co-op model to include graduate and academic lab experiences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Project Summary: The main goal of this research project was to use biomaterials science and engineering to mimic the tumor microenvironment (TME) and gain a deeper understanding of the interaction between tumor cells and dendritic cells (DCs). DCs are essential for directing immune responses. We focused particularly on the impact of hypoxia—an oxygen-deficient condition that tumors create to evade the immune system—on the function of DCs. We aimed to determine if hypoxia affects DC functions such as antigen uptake, migration, cytokine secretion, and T-cell activation. If it does, we sought ways to regulate these functions using localized oxygenation. To this end, we engineered oxygen-generating cryogels (O2-cryogels) to recreate a hypoxic TME and studied how balancing local oxygen levels could overcome hypoxia-driven immunosuppression and regulate DC physiology. Understanding these mechanisms could lead to advanced biomaterials that control immune cell functions, potentially making cancer therapies more effective.

Additionally, the educational goal of this project was to introduce high school students to biomaterials science and engineering through hands-on curricula, research experiences, and STEM field trips to the campus. We also aimed to increase research exposure for underrepresented undergraduate students (Hispanic, African-American, and female) and expand Northeastern University’s (NU) co-op model to include graduate and academic lab experiences. We partnered with NU's Center for STEM Education and programs like Building Bridges, Young Scholars, and the Massachusetts Science Fair to engage students in outreach activities related to our research.

Intellectual Merit: Our research aimed to advance the field of immunoengineering by developing immunomodulatory oxygen-generating biomaterials to control tissue oxygen tension, particularly in tumor masses, and effectively regulate immune cell functions. This approach provides the cancer research community with a platform for more predictable immunomodulation, enhancing the range of immunotherapy options against cancer. It also addresses fundamental questions about the interactions between hypoxia and immune cells and how oxygen supply can regulate immune cell characteristics. This research has the potential to modulate the hypoxic microenvironment around tumors and tailor more efficient anti-cancer immune responses, leveraging the expertise in polymer science and immunoengineering to develop next-generation biomaterials for emerging cancer immunotherapies.

Broader Impacts: The proposed work benefits society by addressing how to modulate and overcome tumor-induced hypoxia to strengthen anti-cancer immune responses and improve cancer therapy outcomes. It enhances our understanding of how the hypoxic tumor microenvironment suppresses immune cells and how an engineered oxygen-releasing biomaterial could reverse this hypoxia, boost anti-cancer immunity, and potentially save millions of lives. The principles of biomaterials science and engineering were integrated into hands-on research and educational activities, particularly with High School students and NU undergraduates, to strengthen their interest in STEM subjects and career awareness. Additionally, the NU co-op education model was expanded to include graduate industrial and undergraduate academic experiences. As an underrepresented faculty member in the Chemical Engineering department at NU, the PI focused on promoting the participation of minorities, particularly Hispanic, African-American, and female students, in these research activities.

Research Findings: We designed and characterized O2-cryogels. By incorporating a higher percentage of calcium peroxide (CaO2) and optimizing the amount of lyophilized catalase enzyme to degrade the toxic hydrogen peroxide produced, we demonstrated efficient oxygen release post-injection and confirmed excellent cytocompatibility and biocompatibility of these biomaterials.We successfully recreated a tumor microenvironment using a hyaluronic acid (HA)-based cryogel scaffold, allowing tumor cells to adhere, proliferate, and form masses. We now better understand how tumor cells create hypoxia and how O2-cryogels can reverse this condition. Our results indicate that hypoxia has a detrimental effect on DC viability and phenotype, converting them to a less effective form with downregulated activation molecules. However, O2-cryogels can prevent these changes, preserving DC functions essential for effective T-cell priming and anti-tumor immunity. We translated these findings to human DCs, showing that O2-cryogels preserve antigen uptake, chemotaxis, and phenotypic maturation in hypoxic conditions. This suggests that HA-based cryogels encapsulating CaO2 particles can be used as minimally invasive oxygen delivery platforms to reverse hypoxia in vivo. Local oxygen supply from cryogel-based vaccines can prevent DC hypoxia, enhancing antigen uptake, activation, and migration, leading to robust anti-tumor immune responses.

In conclusion, this project has provided significant insights into how engineered biomaterials can modulate immune cell functions in hypoxic environments, potentially leading to more effective cancer therapies and contributing to the broader field of immunoengineering. The educational initiatives associated with this project have also promoted STEM education and research involvement among underrepresented students, fostering the next generation of scientists and leaders in biomaterials science, immunology, and engineering.


Last Modified: 07/28/2024
Modified by: Sidi A Bencherif
